column10: ...and we are their commodity.
column11: Oil is a valuable commodity.
column12: Time is a precious commodity.

column9: to be concerned about and want what is best for someone.
column10: They don't necessarily have our best interests at heart...
column11: I know you have my best interests at heart.
column12: She is a good teacher who always has her students' best interests at heart.

column9: to keep someone or something under control.
column10: So we have to, you know, keep them in check and see what they're actually doing.
column11: The government is trying to keep inflation in check.
column12: You need to keep your emotions in check.

column9: a balance achieved between two desirable but incompatible features; a compromise.
column10: There's always a trade-off between privacy and convenience...
column11: There is a trade-off between the cost and the quality of the product.
column12: She had to make a trade-off between her career and her family.

column9: an agreement or a settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions.
column10: We accept a certain level of compromise.
column11: The two sides have reached a compromise.
column12: I'm not willing to compromise my principles.

column9: close observation, especially of a suspected spy or criminal.
column10: Surveillance relates to being watched...
column11: The police have him under surveillance.
column12: The company uses surveillance cameras to monitor its employees.

column9: the condition of being anonymous.
column10: Anonymity is what we probably should have on the internet.
column11: He asked for anonymity to protect his family.
column12: The internet allows people to express their opinions with a degree of anonymity.

column9: dealt with (a situation or person) ineptly or incorrectly.
column10: ...if this information is mishandled...
column11: The company mishandled the customer's complaint.
column12: The government has been accused of mishandling the crisis.

column9: the unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
column10: ...mishandled—through leaks or deliberate misuse...
column11: There have been a number of leaks from government departments.
column12: The leak of the report caused a political scandal.

column9: the intentional use of something for a wrong purpose.
column10: ...through leaks or deliberate misuse...
column11: The deliberate misuse of company funds is a serious offence.
column12: He was accused of the deliberate misuse of his authority.

column9: wrongful or criminal deception intended to result in financial or personal gain.
column10: ...it could lead to fraud, spam, or loss of control over our digital lives.
column11: He was arrested for credit card fraud.
column12: The company was a victim of a major fraud.

column9: irrelevant or unsolicited messages sent over the Internet, typically to a large number of users, for the purposes of advertising, phishing, spreading malware, etc.
column10: ...it could lead to fraud, spam...
column11: My inbox is full of spam.
column12: I need to install a spam filter.

column9: the small print of a contract or agreement, containing conditions or restrictions that are often not noticed.
column10: Understanding the fine print and managing our data-sharing preferences helps us take control.
column11: Always read the fine print before you sign a contract.
column12: The offer seemed too good to be true, and the catch was in the fine print.

column9: a security incident in which sensitive, protected or confidential data is copied, transmitted, viewed, stolen or used by an individual unauthorized to do so.
column10: After the recent data breach, I decided to opt out...
column11: The company announced a major data breach affecting millions of customers.
column12: It's important to change your password after a data breach.

column9: a person or group besides the two primarily involved in a situation, especially a dispute.
column10: ...sharing my data with third parties.
column11: The information will not be shared with third parties without your consent.
column12: The dispute was settled by a third party.

column9: permission for something to happen or agreement to do something.
column10: I probably give consent to a lot of things without realising.
column11: He gave his consent to the operation.
column12: She did not consent to the publication of her photograph.

column9: to choose not to be part of an activity or system.
column10: I decided to opt out of sharing my data with third parties.
column11: You can opt out of the pension scheme if you wish.
column12: She opted out of the school trip.

column9: small files which are stored on a user's computer, designed to hold a modest amount of data specific to a particular client and website.
column10: Do you always accept cookies without thinking about the implications?
column11: You can choose to accept or reject cookies.
column12: I've cleared the cookies from my browser.

column9: the conclusion that can be drawn from something although it is not explicitly stated; a likely consequence of something.
column10: Do you always accept cookies without thinking about the implications?
column11: The new law has serious implications for the economy.
column12: What are the implications of this decision?

column9: a period of time during which a person refrains from using electronic devices such as smartphones or computers.
column10: A digital detox means consciously stepping back from technology...
column11: I'm going on a digital detox this weekend.
column12: A digital detox can help to reduce stress.

column9: spending a lot of time looking at screens.
column10: With our lives increasingly tied to screens...
column11: Many office workers are tied to their screens all day.
column12: It's not healthy to be tied to a screen for long periods.

column9: to be unaware of what time it is.
column10: ...it's easy to lose track of time and feel overwhelmed.
column11: I was so absorbed in my book that I lost track of time.
column12: It's easy to lose track of time when you're on holiday.

column9: feeling that something is too much to deal with.
column10: ...it's easy to lose track of time and feel overwhelmed.
column11: I was overwhelmed by the amount of work I had to do.
column12: She felt overwhelmed with emotion.

column9: in a deliberate and intentional way.
column10: A digital detox means consciously stepping back from technology...
column11: She consciously decided to change her lifestyle.
column12: He was consciously trying to be more positive.

column9: temporarily stopping an activity or involvement in it.
column10: ...consciously stepping back from technology to recharge mentally and emotionally.
column11: He decided to step back from his responsibilities for a while.
column12: It's important to step back from your work and relax sometimes.

column9: to get back your energy after being tired.
column10: ...to recharge mentally and emotionally.
column11: I need a holiday to recharge my batteries.
column12: A good night's sleep will help you to recharge.

column9: to establish a connection or relationship with (someone or something) again.
column10: ...and reconnect with offline hobbies and relationships.
column11: I'm hoping to reconnect with some old friends at the reunion.
column12: It's important to reconnect with nature.

column9: stopping thinking about work or other things that are worrying you.
column10: But actually switching off is often harder than it sounds.
column11: I find it hard to switch off after a busy day at work.
column12: A holiday is a good chance to switch off and relax.

column9: the amount of time spent using a device with a screen such as a smartphone, computer, or television.
column10: How much screen time do you have each day?
column11: Too much screen time can be bad for your eyes.
column12: The parents are trying to limit their children's screen time.

column9: to disconnect (an electrical device) from a power source; to disconnect from the digital world.
column10: I try to unplug from all devices after 9 pm...
column11: Remember to unplug the iron after you've finished.
column12: It's good to unplug and spend some time offline.

column9: the practice of being aware of your body, mind, and feelings in the present moment, in order to create a feeling of calm.
column10: Practising mindfulness helps me resist FOMO...
column11: Mindfulness can help to reduce stress.
column12: She practises mindfulness meditation every day.

column9: limits that define what is acceptable.
column10: Turning off notifications is a simple way to create boundaries.
column11: It's important to set clear boundaries in a relationship.
column12: He has no sense of personal boundaries.

column9: messages or alerts that an app sends you on your phone.
column10: Turning off notifications is a simple way to create boundaries.
column11: I've turned off all the notifications on my phone.
column12: I get too many notifications from social media.

column9: a feeling of anxiety that an exciting or interesting event may currently be happening elsewhere, often aroused by posts seen on social media.
column10: Practising mindfulness helps me resist FOMO...
column11: I think I've got a bit of FOMO.
column12: Social media can create a lot of FOMO.

column9: the ability to make yourself do things you know you should do even when you do not want to.
column10: ...and then self-discipline.
column11: It takes a lot of self-discipline to study every day.
column12: He has no self-discipline.
